The Rev. Mr. McKay arrived from Edmonton yesterday, on Monday evening.

Mr. W. F. Fowle, builder, second the motion for alterations and additions to the Mission chapel.

Masons Brown and Young are hard at work on Mr. W. F. Fowle's new dwelling on Third Street.

Industrious Ink, Caro Croce, Inner Pawl, Chlorate of Potash Tablets, Acid Laxative, etc., are now on sale.

Masonic Band of Ladies' Band is one of the finest and best known on the market. For sale at Clark's Drug Store.

Mr. A. W. R. Markley left for Winnipeg last night, bound for the annual meeting of the Confederation Life Association of Canada.

We notice in an exchange that our old friend Mr. J. Campbell has been appointed an Indian Agent in the North-West.

Parties wanting conveyances can procure them from Alex. Sanderson, Race Street, or by having their orders filled at the Union Hotel.

The brick work on the new Contention and Jail building is progressing rapidly forward. The completion of this work will be delayed in this week.

Hard & Baker have completed the plastering of the upper portion of the new school building at the corner of Sixth and Hamilton streets.

The Marshall brothers are offering for sale their property opposite the two churches on the north side of the street, and the lot and building on Second Street, near the residence of Mr. James.

During last week we had the pleasure of a trip out of the country, and visited the beautiful lake district, which is now covered with fields of grain, a pretty site of fields belonging to Mr. Macdonald, which was all ready for the harvest, and the wheat fields, which was nearly ripe. Mr. McLean is one of our many enterprising farmers who, by his careful management, has been able to secure a harvest of wheat, within the limit of ordinary years.

We are pleased to learn that Mr. Mary's School at Red River College, has undergone several changes both inside and outside, which make a great improvement in the appearance of the school.

It has been added on the outside and renovated very neatly on the inside.

The church is now occupied by the congregation, and their pews filled with Clark's goods.

Churches in the church an ecclesiastical building, and the members of the congregation took place in this church, and Wednesday the meeting of the Synod was held, an assembly of which will appear in our columns shortly.

On Monday night last another meeting was held in St. Paul's Presbyterian Church. The attendance was considerable larger than that of previous ones. Dr. Bain was appointed chairman, and conducted the meeting in a manner calculated to promote harmony.

Mr. McMillan's resignation as a member of the committee was accepted by the congregation, and Mr. McMillan was instructed to vote the Presbytery that said position would be vacant.

NORTHWEST FIRST!

Some time ago an article appeared in the editorial columns of this paper having for its text the expression of opinion by the Leithbridge News that "Our Northwest First," by which they mean to anchor all our candidates' hopes to weather the storms of a territorial election contest successfully, in which we took the opportunity view ourselves that the Dominion first should be the reality of every true Canadian, i.e., Liberal or Conservative." Replying in our issue of the 26th ult., to our remarks, the News claims that we must regard the Northwest battle with all we had to say on the subject, and goes on to declare that what the News meant by Northwest first is not Northwest before the Dominion, but Northwest before anything.

Now, Northwest First does mean Liberal, whether Liberal or Conservative." But how a man having clear and decided views on the great questions of the day, and, as a consequence, having to take stand with one or other of the great political parties, can subscribe to the doctrine North West first was not before, country when principles make parties, and parties give effect to principles, is more than can be understood. Besides, wherein lies the difference between the declarations on the part of the News, since party government is the order of the day, and the motto of the true party man is "with the party, by the party, for the party?" Sure, by God, if awarded, justified in seeking the comments we do insist upon, in the first declaration—if there was a seasonable pause to the correctness of our interpretation of its meaning, in real instance—there can be no mistake now, since it places the Northwest before parties, which means political parties, and of course with the News as nothing but the Dominion Government, no matter how able, no matter whether Reformors or Conservative, Free Traders or Protectionists, no matter what our opinions may be regarding the Dominion, we should be sure to think it would be not only so but also of some honour and dignity, but so earnest, as to think seriously of sending to Ottawa our most representative men who, while thus, according to its own views, would doubtless destroy some "old" political party or one of either of the great political parties, to swallow their prejudices, make political sentiments of themselves, and then proclaim their advantages to be given to the Northwest, for in our opinion, it is no such things as advantage Northwest before centre parties, but as having to prove, just as having to prove, that the Northwest is something more than merely a political movement. If it were not so, more might be said.

We believe that in the North-West, for in our opinion, it is no such thing as advantage Northwest before centre parties, but as having to prove, just as having to prove, that the Northwest is something more than merely a political movement. It is a question of national pride, and it is necessary that the Northwest be made to feel that it is an important part of Canada. SHIFTS OF SALE OF LANDS.

Sheriff Miller's Sale of Lots.

"I have entered a notice of sale of Lots," said Sheriff Miller, at his office yesterday.

"The sale will take place at three o'clock this afternoon," he continued.

"This notice is posted on the bulletin board at the Sheriff's Office," said Mr. Miller.

"The sale is being held because of non-payment of taxes," he explained.

"I am confident the sale will prove to be successful," he added.

"Those interested in purchasing land should come to the Sheriff's Office early," he concluded.
SCHOOL EXAMINATION AND PICNIC.

On the 16th ult., a public examination was held at St. Andrew's School, St. Andrews. The examination was strictly taken advantage of by the trustees and residents to organize a picnic for the termination of the school year. Mr. Andrew Spence, chairman of the school trustees, presided with much tact and enthusiasm over the proceedings.

The examination was held in the school house which, though of no mean dimensions, was wholly inadequate to accommodate the large number of pupils who assembled to do honor to the occasion. Under some little disadvantage from overcrowding, Mr. Spence put the different classes through their oral exercises in excellent style. It is not our intention to longevity but rather to mark the varied and individual industry and individual prominence amongst the pupils. Suffice it to say all the visitors present were convinced of the high degree of efficiency of the school and its work. In all the classes even a casual observer could see the most complete evidence of the thoroughness of the teacher's plan and of thoroughness in his system, while the pupils and their teachers are equally marked by the absence of nervousness, bright and intelligent alive to their work. The reading was characterized by careful attention to the rules of capitalization, while the custom of allowing the pupils to examine each other on the exercises of the day was an excellent method of interest and aid and is a valuable educational factor in the school. The senior classes showed very fair progress in composition and recitation and evinced a considerable knowledge of the elements of grammar, which was all the more commendable when we consider the pupils when we consider the instruction in this branch has hitherto been given nearly entirely, so far as we know, in the home. Writing was judged by a committee of experts chosen from among the visitors. All the work was pronounced very good and the committee's recommendations would have done honor to any school. A special feature in the day's proceedings was the singing by the pupils in all the classes took part. The pieces selected were in good taste and were very effective in indicating the interest taken by Mr. Craig in every department of his work, who may be justly proud of mentioning that a little piece of music had been spoken by two young ladies who had never been within ten thousand miles of the old country, yet sang with such grace and so very correctly that we, as lovers of the grand old Doric of the northern tongues, could hardly believe that they carried away from that bold encampment overlooking the South Saskatchewan to be the only young ladies "banks and brass" of our own country.

We do not know whether at the end of the proceedings the chairman observed as he has done on former occasions, enough at this very point he called us from labor to refreshment? An excellent lunch was provided in a large booth or other form of shelter, and after a short dining-room. Lunch having been eaten ample time was given for the examining pupils to take the large number assembled in the school room where the pupils under the leadership of the Rev. R. N. Smith, the minister of St. Andrew's entertained the audience with a specimen of their singing powers which was greatly appreciated.

The chairman then, in bringing the examination to a close, addressed a few interesting and appropriate words to the pupils and their parents, and after warmly thanking the guests and visitors for their presence and countenance, he called upon Capt. Craig, the chairman, who, speaking on behalf of the guests, expressed the great pleasure they all had in being present, and proceeded shortly to review the day's events in full referring in terms of commendation to the results in the examination in all the departments. He had but to refer to Mr. Gerrard's many qualifications for the duties of his important office, but took this opportunity to express the extent to which he had been able to impart his ample store of knowledge to his pupils, and to assure them that he gratulated the trustees, the parents, and the pupils alike on possessing such a teacher as himself. He then reviewed the oversight of another class of bright and apt scholars.
